label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, January 28, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, advising her to go over seas with her job, discussing the war, and describing their day of surfing. Sidney continues in his letter to describe an abandoned car being swallowed by nature and lament over construction traffic on the island.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
January 28, 1943
Hello Sweetears,
I am writting you from my apartment as I have
given up hope of being able to do so from the office. There
is to much going on and everytime I take a sheet of paper in
my hand and insert it into this old machine and start a letter
to you I end up by endorsing someones orders or ordering a
ton of mimeograph paper for our grinding presses.
Your letter of the 18th. arrived on the morning
mail and I was so delighted to receive it and read everything
you said over twice[,]before the captain came out and seeing me
with an[un]officeial paper in my hand scowled heavily. I think it
is so mean to leave you in America and send people like Helen
to England when you have had more experience travelling and know
foreign lands better than anyone else. I cannot tell you what
to do to get one of those swell jobs because I am not any good
at it myself. Now if the Fuherer was there he would probably
handle you so that Persia would be the first stopping off place
within the week. This I do know that the old saw of "it is who
you know and not what youknow " is as true today as it was the
hour it was coined back in the garden of Eden. To be liked
by everyone is far better than to have the strongest character
in the world and all sorts of ambition, if ones ambition is to
get ahead quickly. Of course I do believe that ability wins
out in the long run, but what a run. There is hardly any
breath left in the body at the end . As I told you in a former
letter you must not sit in that dreary city and wait for me to
come back because no one, I least of all know what my plans are
going to be. I think, simply because I cannot imagine anything
else[,]that we will move up to our new building and be the
administrative officers there, but this may not come ture as
one of our units numbers into the thousands, rather hundreds of
men with a captain at the head and two commanders as excutiove
and administrative officers. Now our captain may go to sea as
he has been trying to for months. In that case the other captain
would undoubtly take charge and Morris and I would be out as
administrators and would apply for a transfer. Then only the
Lord and the Navy Dept. would know where we would be sent. Past
performances mean nothing in sending one to a new post now.
The procedure is that when a new man is needed they grab the first
available one and send him on regar[d]less of whether he knows what
the hell it is all about.
I had a good laugh when I read your letter
saying you thought the war would now go on for two more years.
Just a month ago washington thought that it was all over and
only the spoils of victory remained to be divided, now they
think it will take two years and within a month they will
[End Page 1]
wonder when it will end. I predict 1945. Germany is still
deep in Russia, she has not been driven out of Africa by a
long shot, her submarine warfare is only commencing and she
may try a pincer movement down through Turkey herself. Somehow
I do not see why she should be defeated when she is fighting on
her home soil any faster than Russia was. It must be remembered
that in the last war at the time the Armistice was signed she
was deep in France and her troops were doing very well indeed.
It was the crumbling of the home and not the war front that
forced her surrender. Today with the existing powerful
propaganda machine she will be able to maintain a higher morale
and conseqently will be more difficult to defeat.
Surely Gertie now that you have been in Washington
for so long you must know some of the powers that be, you have
written me of dinners at which you have met them. Won't they
help you obtain an overseas job, give you something to do that
would interest you and use your strength and abiltiy to their
fullest. It does seem a shame to keep you cooped up in that
hot dreary office all the time when you might be somewhere
enjoying the climate as I am even though you may not have a
better job.
We went surfboading today and It was wonderful.
The water was jade in color and very clear so that sitting on
ones board you could l[o]ok down and see nobs of coral and seaweed
that swung back and forth as if blown by the wind. The waves
were too small and broke sharply so that it was difficult to
catch them. I had been swept ashore by one and was paddling
out again when I heard Morris the fat face whoop and saw him
paddling like mad in fron_t of a big comber. It caught up and
lifting the back end of his board started it sliding down the
smooth green surface of the wave,. Little lines of white formed
on either side of the bow as it cut through the water and as
the wave broke the xxxxxxxxxxxxx foam of the crest swept forward
and encirled the board halfxxx its length. Morris stood up
and as he came towards me I yelled "beach boy, beach boy "
deriously . He waved his hand and this threw him off his balance
for a moment he tettered back and forth and then with a forlorn
yell fell over backwards and the board shot up int o the air.
A moment latter he emerged with that wonderful grin on his face
saying "Boy oh Boy, did you see me". We stayed out for on hour
and were so tired when we grounded our boards on the white sand
in front of the club that we had to sit there for five minutes
in order that we might have sufficent strength to pick them up
and curry them to thier lockers. The boards weigh a hundred
pounds and it is quite a trick to lift and handle them. Only
old time Hawniians like us of course are [A]ble to do so. I will
admit that seeing you know me very well that when no one is
looking Morris takes one end of the board and I the other and
we carry it together. This is of course disgraceful, but we
are past the age of caring.
The saddest sight I have seen in years is at the
BOQ. There by the front door is a car its tires flat, its
radiator covered with vines which have twined around the hood,
[End Page 2]
crept into the interior through the windows and wrapped around
the steering wheel. I asked whose car it was and the answer,
an aviators killed at Guadalcan[A]l. No one does anything about
it, waiting for the Goverment to take charge, so there it sits
a green covered tombstone to his memeory. It will probably be
there at the end of the war, only then the vine will have swallowed
it completely and only the radio antennae will be pointing up
upwards.
The noise in front of out building is unbelievable.
Three weeks ago they laid a new street with the aid of tractors ,
drills and extra loud whistles. All trafficX was shunted around
a tiny road in the course of which it became hopelessly snarled.
For the past three days they have been tearing up this road with
the same tractors, recognized several of the men driving them.
The extra loud whis[T]les are there in better condition than ever,
and trafficX is now so tied up that some cars have not moved for
days. I like to see things like this happen. It reminds me of
the frustrations at Medway and priv[u]des a very homy touch. One
realizes that war or no war street depts. are the final arbiters
of our lives, and that they remain supreme long after conquerors
have crumbled in the dust.
Every Hawaiian newspaper pleaded with one to be at
the radio at 4:30 to hear an extraordinary announcemnt. Morris
and I thought the war was going to end, taxes seduced, taxes
raised, ten acres and a mule for every man in the service etc.
so we left the office and sat by a radio. You can imagine our
rage when we heard that simple announcement that was meant to
send the blood coursing through our veins. The President had
been travelling again. This time he had been to North Africa,
a very good place in the winter when icy blasts are blowing down
constitution avenue. Best of all I liked Stalins and Chiang KI
Cheks remark that they were too busy fighting to talk.
Good bye darling, I will write you everyother day
from the apartment at night, and I send you all my best wishes
and love for a job that you will like and that we will be
together soon.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 3]
